section-one.heading: Erosion in New Zealand Landscapes
section-one.paragraph-one: Forests on steep, erosion-prone land significantly reduce landslides and erosion compared to pastures due to their thick  roots and leafy canopies. This root reinforcement effect and umbrella effect keep the soil dry and strong, preventing slips and erosion.
section-one.paragraph-two: However, plantation forests in New Zealand are clear-felled at maturity, typically around 28 years, creating a window of vulnerability for about six years until the new crop establishes itself. During this period, the risk of erosion increases, and landslides can move woody debris downslope.

section-two.heading: Transparent and Sustainable Forestry Planning
section-two.paragraph-one: The Forestry Catchment Planner aims to create a transparent, cohesive system for better understanding intergenerational harvesting cycles on a catchment scale.
section-two.paragraph-two: The tool provides insights into forestry stand locations, recent harvests, and data on erosion susceptibility hazard for future harvesting schedules.
section-two.paragraph-three: This enables effective environmental stewardship, improving water quality, promoting healthier ecosystems, and facilitating better holistic planning for future planting and harvesting.
